name: Fraser Fir
climate: Fraser Firs thrive in cool, temperate climates where winters are cold.
They prefer areas with high humidity levels, ensuring healthy growth.
They are typically found at altitudes of 900 to 2,000 meters.
These trees require well-drained locations to prevent root rot.
sunlight: Fraser Firs require full sun exposure to grow properly and remain healthy.
They can tolerate partial shade but may not grow as vigorously.
Direct sunlight helps the needles to stay lush and green year-round.
Avoid planting in areas where they're shaded by larger trees or buildings.
watering: Fraser Firs need consistent moisture, particularly during the growing season.
It's essential to maintain soil moisture, especially in dry spells.
Over-watering can lead to root rot, so soil must drain well.
Mulching can help retain moisture and regulate soil temperature.
soil: Fraser Firs require acidic soil with a pH range between 5.5 and 6.5.
They do best in sandy loam soils that allow for free drainage.
Root systems prefer deep, loose soil that is rich in organic matter.
Compacted or heavy clay soils can hinder root growth and health.
extra_care_tip: Ensure adequate air circulation to prevent fungal diseases on needles.
Pruning should be done in late winter to shape and remove any dead wood.
